overview_metadata.overview_subtitle: Rational Exponents and Graphs of Exponential Functions
overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students determine output values for <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></msup></math> when the input values are non-integers. They connect expressions with rational exponents to those in radical notation. Students explore horizontal asymptotes on different graphs, analyzing end behavior, particularly as the x-values approach negative infinity. They convert between expressions with rational exponents and those in radical notation.

overview_item_data_items: I can explain how rational exponents extend the properties of integer exponents and how they relate to radicals.
I can rewrite radical expressions using rational exponents, and rational exponents using radicals.
I can apply exponent properties to rewrite expressions involving rational exponents and radicals.
I can write and solve exponential equations using rational exponents and common bases.
You can use multiple representations such as tables, equations, and graphs to represent exponential situations.
You can use Properties of Powers to rewrite numeric and algebraic expressions involving integer and rational exponents.
The Properties of Powers also apply to radical expressions because you can rewrite radical expressions as rational exponents.

You can rewrite a rational expression of the form <math><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mrow><mo>/</mo></mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup></math> as a radical expression, <math><mroot><msup><mi>a</mi><mi>m</mi></msup><mi>n</mi></mroot></math> or <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mroot><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi></mroot><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>m</mi></msup></math>.
Use common bases and properties of exponents to solve simple exponential equations.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students determine the side lengths of squares and cubes given the area or volume.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: The Square Root Constant Ratio of an Exponential Function
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students examine how changing the input interval affects the constant multiplier in an exponential function.
Students explore the graphs of exponential functions for input values less than 0.
Students practice writing radicals as powers and writing powers as radicals.
Students use rational exponents and radical notation to rewrite expressions.
